text: here's a common kitchen conundrum that I
know a lot of people have overcooked dry
crumbly fish today I'm going to show you
the easiest way to cook and prepare fish
and you'll be making it every single
night of the week now when I talk about
overcooked fish you can see what I mean
here
most fish especially fatty fish like
this salmon it has a lot of oil in it
which secretes when you overcook it at a
high high temperature I'm going to show
you the simplest way to avoid that now
I'm using salmon today but you could use
any fish and when you're shopping for
fish try to find a sustainable source
right here in front of me I have wild
salmon versus farms them and you can see
the difference in the color of the flesh
the farmed salmon has a lighter color
doesn't have a very intense flavor it's
kind of mild but the wild salmon has a
really delicious flavor and that's
because of the diet because it doesn't
have a feed that it's fed it just eats
out in the wild so I'm going to use the
wild salmon today and a liberal
sprinkling of some oil just kind of
gently coat the fish and season it up
with some salt and freshly ground pepper
super simple nothing fancy here now I
have a nonstick skillet heating over
medium high heat I'm going to add a
little bit more oil to the pan and you
can see that it's nice and hot the oil
is dancing around the pan and I'm going
to place the fish skin side down and
what this does is it gets a really nice
crisp sear to the skin it crisps it up
and makes it crunchy and even more
delicious so into the pan and then we're
going to cook the fish in the oven at
350 degrees a lower temperature so we're
taking it from this direct heat or
moving it to an indirect heat and what
it does to the proteins in the fish it
coils them up and when you do it at a
lower temperature it coils the protein
slowly if you do it at a high high
temperature it coils the proteins up and
constricts them and what that does is it
expels moisture in fat and that's what
you have here with this salmon filet you
can see that the moisture and the fat
has been pushed out of the salmon filet
leaving it nice
so it's been a few minutes the salmon
skin is nice and brown and I'm going to
give it a flip and maybe a minute or so
on this side and right into the oven to
finish cooking all right so I'm going to
go right into the oven 350 degrees for
about five to seven minutes depending on
the thickness of the fish so it's been
about five minutes and I want to show
you a little trick here how you can tell
whether or not the fish is done if you
take a cake tester or if you use the
thin paring knife like this and you
insert it into the center of your fish
filet and you pull it out you should be
able to feel some warmth and you want
warmth then you can touch it to the
underside of your lip you can touch to
your hand and you know if the knife is
warm the fish is fully cooked in the
center so I'm going to just put this
right on to my plate and I like just a
little bit of lemon some butter would be
really nice you would create a wonderful
sauce on the plate and there you have it
perfectly cooked fish and all it really
takes is a few minutes and a few tricks
if you have any kitchen conundrums that
you need solved write in the comments

will solve whatever kitchen problems you
may have
